\method: Mastering Multi-turn Conversational Recommendation with Strategic Planning and Monte Carlo Tree Search

Abstract

Conversational Recommender Systems (CRS) proactively engage users in interactive dialogues to elicit user preferences and provide personalized recommendations. Existing methods train Reinforcement Learning (RL)-based agent with greedy action selection or sampling strategy, and may suffer from suboptimal conversational planning. To address this, we present a novel Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)-based CRS framework \method. \methodconsists of a conversational agent (ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent) and a conversational planner (ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner). ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner builds a conversational search tree with MCTS based on the initial actions proposed by ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent to find conversation plans. The best conversation plans from ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner are used to guide the training of ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent, creating a self-training loop where ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent can iteratively improve its capability for conversational planning. Furthermore, we propose an efficient variant ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e for trade-off between training efficiency and performance. Extensive experiments on four benchmark datasets validate the effectiveness of our approach, showing that \methodoutperforms the state-of-the-art baselines.

: Mastering Multi-turn Conversational Recommendation with Strategic Planning and Monte Carlo Tree Search

1 Introduction

Conversational Recommender Systems (CRSs) are developed to proactively engage users with interactive dialogues to understand user preferences and provide highly personalized recommendations Christakopoulou etÂ al. (2016); Lei etÂ al. (2020b). For example, on an online dining platform such as Yelp Lei etÂ al. (2020b), CRS can chat with users through natural language dialogues (e.g., ask a question like, â€œWhat is your preferred food type?â€) and recommend products that best match the usersâ€™ preferences expressed in the conversation. Among different settings of CRS Sun and Zhang (2018); Deng etÂ al. (2021); He etÂ al. (2023), the Multi-turn Conversational Recommendation (MCR) settingÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020b, c); Deng etÂ al. (2021) is popular as it can interact/communicate with users multiple times (i.e., multiple turns) to iteratively learn user preferences Fu etÂ al. (2020); Jannach etÂ al. (2021). In this work, we develop an innovative Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)-based MCR framework to enhance the strategic conversational planning ability for MCR, offering a fresh perspective for handling complex conversation environments and enhancing user experiences.

A key of MCR is to decide what action (asking a question on specific attribute values or recommending specific items) to take at each conversational turnâ€”a conversational turn consists of the CRS taking an action and the user responding to that actionâ€”to effectively elicit information on user preferences and make personalized recommendations Fu etÂ al. (2020); Lei etÂ al. (2020a). To achieve this, previous methods formulated MCR as a Marchovian Decision Process (MDP) Bellman (1957), and trained policy-based Sun and Zhang (2018); Lei etÂ al. (2020b) or value-based Deng etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2022) agents via Reinforcement Learning (RL) to learn conversation strategies. Despite promising, these methods could suffer from myopic actions and limited planning capability due to the following reasons. First, they base their planning solely on observations of the current state (e.g., items that the user indicates a negative preference for) without exploring potential future states. As a result, they could take myopic actionsÂ Anthony etÂ al. (2017); Cohen etÂ al. (2022). Second, they generate conversation trajectories, also referred to as conversation plans, by sequentially sampling actions, and thus could suffer from the cumulative error, especially when generating long trajectories for planningÂ Kumar etÂ al. (2019); Lan etÂ al. (2020).

To address these limitations, we present a novel MCTS-based MCR frameworkâ€”Strategic Action Planning with Intelligent Exploration Non-myopic Tactics, referred to as \method. \methodcomprises a conversational agent, referred to as ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent, where ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent utilizes an MCTS-based algorithm, referred to as ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner, to plan conversations. ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent builds a global information graph and two personalized graphs with dedicated graph encoders to extract the representation of the conversational states, and synergizes a policy network and a Q-network to decide specific actions based on the learned state representations. ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner leverages MCTS Kocsis and SzepesvÃ¡ri (2006); Coulom (2007) to simulate future conversations with lookahead explorations. This non-myopic conversational planning process ensures ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner can strategically plan conversations that maximize the cumulative reward (a numerical signal measuring whether the action taken by ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent is good or not), instead of greedily selecting actions based on immediate reward. The best conversation plans with the highest cumulative rewards found by ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner are used to guide the training of ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent. In this way, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent can engage in a self-training loopÂ Silver etÂ al. (2017)â€”collecting trajectories from multiple conversation simulations and training the ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent on selected, high-rewarded trajectoriesâ€”to iteratively improve its planning capability. During inference, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent can directly make well-informed decisions without ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner, since it inherits the ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -plannerâ€™s expertise in strategic and non-myopic planning.

To make MCTS scalable w.r.t. the size of items and attributes, we introduce a hierarchical action selection process Nachum etÂ al. (2018), and two action types: ğšŠğšœğš”ğšŠğšœğš”\mathtt{ask}typewriter_ask and ğš›ğšğšŒğš›ğšğšŒ\mathtt{rec}typewriter_rec. At each turn, instead of searching over all the items and attribute values, ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner builds a conversational search tree (FigureÂ 1) that only searches over the two action types and uses the Q-network to decide the specific action, thus greatly reducing the search space.

We evaluate \methodagainst 9 state-of-the-art CRS baselines, and show \methodsignificantly outperforms baselines on 4 benchmark datasets. Our case study also shows that the action strategies of \methodare beneficial for information seeking and recommendation success in the conversations.

Furthermore, we develop an efficient variant of \method, denoted as ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e. Different from \method, which is trained on selected, high-rewarded trajectories, ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e consumes all trajectories found by ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner for training via a listwise ranking loss. As a result, ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e requires less cost of collecting training trajectories compared to \method, and enables superior efficiency.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We present \method, a novel MCR framework synergizing an MCTS-based ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner and an ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent with a self-training loop to iteratively improve ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agentâ€™s planning capability. To the best of our knowledge, \methodis the first to leverage an MCTS-based planning algorithm to achieve strategic, non-myopic planning for MCR.

  • â€¢

    We further develop ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e, an efficient variant trained on all trajectories from ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner via a listwise ranking loss. ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e addresses the efficiency issue with MCTS while maintaining similar performance with \method.

  • â€¢

    Our extensive experiments show both \methodand ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e outperform the state-of-the-art baselines. Our case study shows \methodcan strategically take actions that enhance information seeking and recommendation success.

2 Related Work

CRS understands user preferences through interactive natural language conversations to provide personalized recommendations Fu etÂ al. (2020); Jannach etÂ al. (2021). Early methods Christakopoulou etÂ al. (2016); Sun and Zhang (2018) ask users about their desired attribute values to narrow down the list of candidate items to recommend, but are limited under the single-turn setting, as they can only recommend once in a conversation. To address this, multi-turn CRSs allow for multiple turns of question inquiries and item recommendations. For example, ğ™´ğ™°ğšğ™´ğ™°ğš\mathop{\mathtt{EAR}}\limitstypewriter_EAR Lei etÂ al. (2020b) adjusts the conversation strategy based on the userâ€™s feedbacks with a three-staged process. ğš‚ğ™²ğ™¿ğšğš‚ğ™²ğ™¿ğš\mathop{\mathtt{SCPR}}\limitstypewriter_SCPR Lei etÂ al. (2020c) models MCR as a path reasoning problem over the knowledge graph of users, items, and attribute values. ğš„ğ™½ğ™¸ğ™²ğ™¾ğšğ™½ğš„ğ™½ğ™¸ğ™²ğ™¾ğšğ™½\mathop{\mathtt{UNICORN}}\limitstypewriter_UNICORN Deng etÂ al. (2021) introduces a graph-based RL framework for MCR. ğ™¼ğ™²ğ™¼ğ™¸ğ™¿ğ™»ğ™¼ğ™²ğ™¼ğ™¸ğ™¿ğ™»\mathop{\mathtt{MCMIPL}}\limitstypewriter_MCMIPL Zhang etÂ al. (2022) develops a multi-interest policy learning framework to understand userâ€™s interests over multiple attribute values. ğ™·ğšğšğ™²ğšğš‚ğ™·ğšğšğ™²ğšğš‚\mathop{\mathtt{HutCRS}}\limitstypewriter_HutCRS Qian etÂ al. (2023) introduces a user interest tracing module to track user preferences. ğ™²ğ™¾ğšğ™´ğ™²ğ™¾ğšğ™´\mathop{\mathtt{CORE}}\limitstypewriter_CORE Jin etÂ al. (2023) designs a CRS framework powered by large language models with user-friendly prompts and interactive feedback mechanisms. Chen etÂ al. (2019) and Montazeralghaem etÂ al. (2021) build a tree-structured index with clustering algorithms to handle the large scale of items and attribute values in MCR. Different from these methods, \methodis able to iteratively improve its planning ability through self-training on demonstrations from MCTS, allowing for more informed and non-myopic conversation strategies. Additional related works on reinforcement learning for CRS are available in AppendixÂ B.

4 Method

We introduce \method, an MCTS-based MCR framework that achieves strategic and non-myopic conversational planning. \methodformulates MCR as an MDP with a hierarchical action selection process (SectionÂ 4.1). A conversational agent (ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent) observes the current state and decides the actions in each conversational turn (SectionÂ 4.2), a conversational planner (ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner) leverages an MCTS-based algorithm to plan conversations (SectionÂ 4.3), and ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent engages in a self-training loop with guidance from ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner (SectionÂ 4.4). An framework overview of \methodis in FigureÂ 2 and the training algorithm is in AlgorithmÂ 1. We summarize all the notations in AppendixÂ A.

4.2 ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent

ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent comprises three components: the state encoder, the policy network, and the Q-network. Conversation Simulation

To predict how the future conversation unfolds, ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner continues to simulate conversations between ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent and the user until the conversation succeeds or fails. Starting from the last expanded node, at each turn, the policy network decides the action type, while the Q-network decides the specific action.

Improving Training Efficiency

This aforementioned training process guarantees the quality of training data by selecting only the high-rewarded trajectories, but may be inefficient because it requires a large number of simulations to collect enough high-rewarded trajectories. To improve efficiency, we further propose a variant ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e. Instead of using only the highest-rewarded trajectories, ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e makes full use of all the trajectories found by ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner. As ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent usually requires fixed number of training trajectories to converge, utilizing all the trajectoriesâ€”rather than just a selected fewâ€”greatly reduces the cost of collecting trajectories and improves training efficiency.

Since some trajectories are good while others are suboptimal (e.g., user quits the conversation after Tmaxsubscriptğ‘‡maxT_{\text{max}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT turns), we would like to encourage Ï€Ï•â¢(ot|st)subscriptğœ‹italic-Ï•conditionalsubscriptğ‘œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡\pi_{\phi}(o_{t}|s_{t})italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to increase the likelihood for good trajectories and decrease the likelihood for the suboptimal ones. To this end, we employ the Plackett-Luce model Luce (1959); Plackett (1975) to train Ï€Ï•â¢(ot|st)subscriptğœ‹italic-Ï•conditionalsubscriptğ‘œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡\pi_{\phi}(o_{t}|s_{t})italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with listwise likelihood estimations. 5 Experimental Settings

Datasets

We evaluate \methodon 4 benchmark datasets: Yelp Lei etÂ al. (2020b), LastFM Lei etÂ al. (2020b), Amazon-Book McAuley etÂ al. (2015) and MovieLens Harper and Konstan (2015). Dataset details are available in AppendixÂ F.1.

User Simulator

Training and evaluating CRS with real-world user interactions can be impractically expensive at scale. To address this issue, we adopt the user simulator approachÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020b) and simulate a conversation for each user as detailed in AppendixÂ F.2. Note that this user simulator is widely adopted in the literatureÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020b); Deng etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2022); Zhao etÂ al. (2023); Qian etÂ al. (2023) and studies show the simulations are of high quality and suitable for evaluation purposesÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020a); Zhang and Balog (2020); Zhang etÂ al. (2022), allowing for large-scale evaluations at a relatively low cost.

Evaluation Metrics

Following the literature Deng etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2022), the Success Rate (SR) is adopted to measure the ratio of successful recommendations within Tmaxsubscriptğ‘‡maxT_{\text{max}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT turns; Average Turn (AT) to evaluate the average number of conversational turns; and hDCG Deng etÂ al. (2021) to evaluate the ranking order of the ground-truth item among the list of all the recommended items.

Baselines and Implementation Details

We choose 9 state-of-the-art baselines for a comprehensive evaluation, including a Large Language Model (LLM)-powered baseline COREÂ Jin etÂ al. (2023). Baseline details are in AppendixÂ F.4. Implementation details of \methodare in AppendixÂ F.5.

6 Experimental Results

6.1 Overall Performance Comparison

We compare \methodwith 9 state-of-the-art baselines and report the experimental results in TableÂ 1. We have the following observations:

(1) \methodachieves consistent improvement over baselines in terms of all metrics on all the datasets, with an average improvement of 9.1% (SR), 6.0% (AT) and 11.1% (hDCG) compared with the best baseline. Different from baselines, which base their planning solely on the observation of current state without looking ahead, \methodforesees how the future conversation unfolds with an MCTS-based planning algorithm. This enables \methodto take actions that maximize the cumulative rewards instead of settling for the immediate reward, enabling strategic, non-myopic conversational planning and superior performances.

(2) \methodsubstantially outperforms baselines in datasets demanding strong strategic planning capability from the CRS. The performance gain of \methodis higher on datasets with a larger AT (Yelp and Amazon-Book) compared to datasets with a smaller AT (LastFM and MovieLens), and higher AT in these datasets indicates the need for more strategic planning over long conversational turns. Compared with baselines, \methodis equipped with ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner and excels in conversational planning, hence showing remarkable improvements on these two datasets.

(3) ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e outperforms all baselines on recommendation success rate. Although the training data for ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e still contain a portion of low-quality trajectories, ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e still significantly outperforms the best baselines across most metrics, indicating that ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e is a good trade-off between efficiency and performance.

6.2 Efficiency Analysis

Training efficiency of \methodand ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e is highly comparable to the baselines. As shown in TableÂ 3, ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e takes similar training time with baselines as it collects all the trajectories from MCTS and do not incur additional search cost. Even with \method, the training time is only about 2 times longer than baselines. This is because conversation simulation only requires forward propagation without gradient backward, so even conducting 20 rollouts per user will not significantly reduce efficiency. Also note that during inference, the efficiency of \methodis comparable with baselines, as tree search is not required during inference.

6.3 Ablation Study

To validate the effectiveness of the key components, we conduct ablation studies and report the results in TableÂ 2. We have the following observations:

(1) Each graphâ€”ğ’¢,ğ’¢+,ğ’¢âˆ’ğ’¢superscriptğ’¢superscriptğ’¢\mathcal{G},\mathcal{G}^{+}\!,\mathcal{G}^{-}caligraphic_G , caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is vital for ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent to encode the state information. Removing each graph from ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent degrades performance, verifying the necessity of each graph in state encoding: global information graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G is crucial for mining user-item relations and item-attribute value associations, while positive (ğ’¢+superscriptğ’¢\mathcal{G}^{+}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and negative (ğ’¢âˆ’superscriptğ’¢\mathcal{G}^{-}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) feedback graphs are vital for capturing usersâ€™ preferences (likes/dislikes on items and attribute values) expressed in the conversation.

(2) Both the policy network and the Q-network are critical to conversational planning. We design two variants: replacing the policy network with random action type selection (w/o Pol. net.); replacing the Q-network with entropy-based action selection (w/o Q-net.). Performance drops in both variants suggest both networks are crucial for hierarchical action selection, and the absence of an informed decision maker, either at the action type or the action level, leads to poor conversational planning.

(3) Guidance from ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner is crucial for ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent to achieve strategic conversational planning. Removing ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner and training ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent on sampled on-policy trajectories as inÂ Deng etÂ al. (2021) degrades the performance, because sampled trajectories may bring cumulative errors and biased estimationsÂ Kumar etÂ al. (2019); Lan etÂ al. (2020), resulting in suboptimal conversational planning. By contrast, the high-rewarded conversation plans from ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner offers robust guidance for ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent and boosts its capability for strategic planning.

6.4 Hyperparameter Sensitivity

We study \methodâ€™s performance sensitivity to the exploration factor wğ‘¤witalic_w and the rollout number Nğ‘\!N\!italic_N, as detailed in AppendixÂ F.6. Our major conclusions are: the performance remains robust to large wğ‘¤witalic_w but drops with small wğ‘¤witalic_w. This suggests that \methodfavours exploration over exploitation during conversational tree search. Additionally, the performance notably improves when increasing from N=1ğ‘1N{=}1italic_N = 1 to N=20ğ‘20N{=}20italic_N = 20, and remains stable and satisfactory after N>20ğ‘20N{>}20italic_N > 20. This suggests that setting N=20N20N{=}20italic_N = 20 can strike a good balance between efficiency (small NNNitalic_N) and performance (large NNNitalic_N).

7 Conclusion

We present \method, a novel MCR framework with strategic and non-myopic conversational planning tactics. \methodadopts a hierarchical action selection process, builds a conversational search tree with MCTS, and selects the high-rewarded conversation plans to train ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent. During inference, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent can make well-informed decisions without ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -planner, as it inherits ğš‚â¢-plannerğš‚-planner\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-planner}}\limitstypewriter_S -plannerâ€™s expertise in strategic planning. Furthermore, we develop a variant ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e to address the efficiency issue with MCTS. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets verify the effectiveness of our framework.

8 Limitations

First, our framework only supports searching over two types of actions (ğšŠğšœğš”ğšŠğšœğš”\mathtt{ask}typewriter_ask and ğš›ğšğšŒğš›ğšğšŒ\mathtt{rec}typewriter_rec) so far, which cannot search at a more fine-grained level (e.g., defining action types as â€œrecommending items with a five-star ratingâ€, â€œrecommending items with a three-star ratingâ€, rather than just â€œrecommending itemsâ€). For future work, we plan to adopt advanced action abstraction techniques Bai etÂ al. (2016) to divide the search space at more fine-grained levels. Second, training \methodrequires conducting multiple simulated rollouts for each user, which introduces additional computational cost compared with existing methods. For future work, we plan to further improve the training efficiency of \methodby adopting parallel acceleration methods Chaslot etÂ al. (2008) for MCTS. Third, while the user simulator approach can provide high quality simulations for the conversationÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020a); Zhang and Balog (2020); Zhang etÂ al. (2022), it may not fully represent the dynamics and complexities of user behaviors in the real-world situations. This issue may be partially addressed by developing an LLM-based user simulator that fully utilizes the human-likeliness of LLMs to better simulate user behaviors in the conversation for future work.

While it is our aspiration that CRS can provide personalized and user-friendly recommendations if correctly deployed, we also acknowledge that unintended uses of CRS may pose concerns on fairness and bias issues Shen etÂ al. (2022), which may be a potential risk for CRS but can be mitigated with debiasing algorithms as in the literatureÂ Fu etÂ al. (2021); Lin etÂ al. (2022).

9 Ethics Statement

All datasets used in this research are from public benchmark open-access datasets, which are anonymized and do not pose privacy concerns.

Appendix B Additional Related Works

Reinforcement Learning for CRS

Reinforcement Learning (RL) has achieved great success in tasks requiring strategic planning in complex and interactive environments, such as computer Go Silver etÂ al. (2016, 2017) and dialogue planning Yu etÂ al. (2023); He etÂ al. (2024). RL is also employed to train CRS agents to make strategic actions, and current RL-based CRSs can be mainly categorized into two types of methods: (1) policy-based methods, which train a policy network that directly outputs the probability of taking each action Sun and Zhang (2018); Lei etÂ al. (2020a), and (2) value-based methods, which train a Q-network van Hasselt etÂ al. (2016) to estimate the Q-value of actions Deng etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2022). Despite promising, these CRS methods may suffer from myopic conversational planning and suboptimal decisions due to their greedy action selection and sampling strategy. In contrast to these methods, our new \methodis able to achieve strategic and non-myopic conversational planning through an MCTS-based planning and self-training algorithm.

Appendix C Details of the State Encoder

Transformer-based aggregator fuses the information from the graph encoders, and captures the sequential relationships among items and attribute values mentioned in the conversation history. Appendix F Experimental Details

F.1 Dataset Details and Statistics

We evaluate \methodon four public benchmark recommendation datasets: Yelp Lei etÂ al. (2020b), LastFM Lei etÂ al. (2020b), Amazon-Book McAuley etÂ al. (2015); He and McAuley (2016) and MovieLens Harper and Konstan (2015). The statistics of the datasets after preprocessing are presented in TableÂ A2 and the details of the datasets are introduced as follows:

  • â€¢

    Yelp111https://www.yelp.com/dataset/: This dataset contains usersâ€™ reviews on business venues such as restaurants and bars. Lei etÂ al. (2020b) build a 2-layer taxonomy for the original attribute values for this dataset, and we adopt the categories from the first layer as attribute types, the categories from the second layer as attribute values.

  • â€¢

    LastFM222https://grouplens.org/datasets/hetrec-2011/: This dataset contains usersâ€™ listen records for music artists from an online music platform. Following the literatureÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020a); Zhang etÂ al. (2022), we adopt a clustering algorithm to categorize the original attribute values into 34 attribute types.

  • â€¢

    Amazon-Book333https://jmcauley.ucsd.edu/data/amazon/: The Amazon review dataset McAuley etÂ al. (2015); He and McAuley (2016) is a large-scale collection of online shopping data featuring usersâ€™ product reviews across various domains. We select the book domain from this collection. Following the literatureÂ Wang etÂ al. (2019) we choose relations and entities within the knowledge graph as attribute types and attribute values, and only retain entities associated with at least 10 items to ensure dataset quality.

  • â€¢

    MovieLens444https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/Harper and Konstan (2015): This dataset contains usersâ€™ activities in an online movie recommendation platform. We use the version with about 20M interactions, select entities and relations within the knowledge graph as attribute values, and only retain the user-item interactions with the userâ€™s ratings greater than 3 to ensure the quality of the dataset.

F.2 Details of the User Simulator

Training and evaluating CRS with real user interactions can be impractically expensive at scale. To address this issue, we follow the literatureÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020b); Deng etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2022); Zhao etÂ al. (2023); Qian etÂ al. (2023) and simulate a conversation session for each observed user-item set interaction pair (u,ğ’±â¢(u))ğ‘¢ğ’±ğ‘¢(u,\mathcal{V}(u))( italic_u , caligraphic_V ( italic_u ) ) in the dataset. In each simulated conversation, we regard an item viâˆˆğ’±â¢(u)subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ’±ğ‘¢v_{i}\in\mathcal{V}(u)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_V ( italic_u ) as the ground-truth target item. Each conversation is initialized with a user specifying preference on an attribute value p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that this user clearly prefers, which is randomly chosen from the shared attribute values of all items in ğ’±â¢(u)ğ’±ğ‘¢\mathcal{V}(u)caligraphic_V ( italic_u ). As the conversation continues, in each turn, the simulated user feedback follows these rules: (1) when the CRS asks a question, the user will only accept attribute values associated with any item in ğ’±â¢(u)ğ’±ğ‘¢\mathcal{V}(u)caligraphic_V ( italic_u ) and reject others; (2) when the CRS recommends a list of items, the user will accept it only if at least one item in ğ’±â¢(u)ğ’±ğ‘¢\mathcal{V}(u)caligraphic_V ( italic_u ) is in the recommendation list; (3) the user will become impatient after Tmax=15subscriptğ‘‡max15T_{\text{max}}=15italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 15 turns and quit the conversation.

A higher value implies that the ground-truth item has a higher ranking, and hence indicates a better performance for the CRS. F.4 Details of Baseline Methods

For a comprehensive evaluation, we compare \methodwith the following baselines:

  • â€¢

    Max Entropy Lei etÂ al. (2020b). This method chooses to ask for attribute values with the maximum entropy among candidate items, or chooses to recommend the top-ranked items with certain probability.

  • â€¢

    Abs Greedy Christakopoulou etÂ al. (2016). This method only recommends items in each turn without asking questions. If the recommended items are rejected, the model updates by treating them as negative samples.

  • â€¢

    CRM Sun and Zhang (2018). This method adopts a policy network to decide when and what to ask. As it is originally designed for single-turn CRS, we follow Lei etÂ al. (2020b) to adapt it to the MCR setting.

  • â€¢

    EAR Lei etÂ al. (2020b). This method designs a three-stage strategy to better converse with users. It first builds predictive models to estimate user preferences, then learns a policy network to take action, and finally updates the recommendation model with reflection mechanism.

  • â€¢

    SCPR Lei etÂ al. (2020c). This method models CRS as an interactive path reasoning problem over the knowledge graph of users, items and attribute values. It leverages the graph structure to prune irrelevant candidate attribute values and adopts a policy network to choose actions.

  • â€¢

    UNICORN Deng etÂ al. (2021). This method designs a unified CRS policy learning framework with graph-based state representation learning and deep Q-learning.

  • â€¢

    MCMIPL Zhang etÂ al. (2022). This method develops a multi-choice questions based multi-interest policy learning framework for CRS, which enables users to answer multi-choice questions in attribute combinations.

  • â€¢

    HutCRS Qian etÂ al. (2023). This method proposes a user interest tracking module integrated with the decision-making process of the CRS to better understand the preferences of the user.

  • â€¢

    CORE Jin etÂ al. (2023). This method is a Large Language Model (LLM)-powered CRS chatbot with user-friendly prompts and interactive feedback mechanisms.

F.5 Implementation Details

Following the literatureÂ Zhang etÂ al. (2022) for a more realistic multi-choice setting, if ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent decides to ask, top-Kpsubscriptğ¾ğ‘K_{p}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT attribute values with the same attribute type will be asked from the candidate attribute value set ğ’«tcsubscriptsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}^{c}_{t}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to form a multi-choice question; and if ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent decides to recommend, top-Kvsubscriptğ¾ğ‘£K_{v}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT items will be recommended from the candidate item set ğ’±tcsubscriptsuperscriptğ’±ğ‘ğ‘¡\mathcal{V}^{c}_{t}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Following the literatureÂ Lei etÂ al. (2020c); Deng etÂ al. (2021), each dataset is randomly split into train, validation and test by a 7:1.5:1.5 ratio. We set the embedding dimension dğ‘‘ditalic_d as 64, batch size as 128. We adopt an Adam optimizer Kingma and Ba (2015) with a learning rate of 1e-4. We set the discount factor Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ as 0.999. The memory size of experience replay is set as 10000. For the state encoder, the number of the global information graph encoder layers Lgsubscriptğ¿ğ‘”L_{g}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is set as 2, and both the number of the positive feedback graph encoder layer Lasubscriptğ¿ğ‘L_{a}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the number of the negative feedback graph encoder layer Lnsubscriptğ¿ğ‘›L_{n}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are set as 1, the number of the Transformer-based aggregator layers are set as 2, and we follow the literatureÂ Deng etÂ al. (2020b); Deng etÂ al. We set the default exploration factor wğ‘¤witalic_w as 1.5, the default number of rollouts Nğ‘Nitalic_N as 20, and variants with different wğ‘¤witalic_w and Nğ‘Nitalic_N are explored in SectionÂ 6.4.

F.6 Hyper-parameter Sensitivity

Exploration and Exploitation

The exploration factor wğ‘¤witalic_w controls the balance between exploration and exploitation. To study its impact, we set wğ‘¤witalic_w from 0.0 (exploitation only) to 5.0 (mostly favours exploration) and plot the success rate in FigureÂ A1. We find that the performance remains stable and satisfactory with high exploration, but drops with only exploitation. This is probably because our conversational search tree has a very small search space (ğšŠğšœğš”ğšŠğšœğš”\mathtt{ask}typewriter_ask and ğš›ğšğšŒğš›ğšğšŒ\mathtt{rec}typewriter_rec), so high exploration does not incur much cost and also ensures thorough evaluation of different action strategies, while high exploitation may prevent the conversational search tree from discovering the optimal action strategy and lead to myopic conversational planning.

Influence of MCTS rollouts

To study the influence of MCTS rollouts, we set Nğ‘Nitalic_N from 1 (equivalent to disabling MCTS, as there is no selection and reward back-propagation when N=1ğ‘1N=1italic_N = 1) from 50 and plot the success rate and training time (on a single Tesla V100 GPU) in FigureÂ A2. Unsurprisingly, we find that more rollouts increases the chance of discovering the optimal trajectory and lead to better performance, while disabling MCTS shows the worst performance. Nevertheless, we should also note that more rollouts bring additional computational cost, and setting N=20ğ‘20N=20italic_N = 20 can achieve a good trade-off between efficiency and performance.

F.7 Additional Analysis on Action Strategies

To gain an insight into the strategic planning capability of \method, we identify some typical action strategies of \methodin FigureÂ A3 that are helpful for information seeking and recommendation success in the conversation. We denote A as the action type ğšŠğšœğš”ğšŠğšœğš”\mathtt{ask}typewriter_ask, R as the action type ğš›ğšğšŒğš›ğšğšŒ\mathtt{rec}typewriter_rec, â€¦ as the continuation of the conversation, <end> as the success of the conversation, and we find the following common action strategies:

  • â€¢

    â€¦AARRâ€¦: This action strategy occurs frequently during the conversation. ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent first asks the user two questions consecutively to gather crucial information on user preference, and then quickly narrows down the candidate item list by making two targeted recommendation attempts. This strategy is highly effective because it allows the ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent to tailor its recommendations to the userâ€™s preferences based on the key information obtained from the two questions. Furthermore, based on the userâ€™s feedback from the two recommendation attempts, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent can promptly reflect upon its action strategy and make necessary adjustments to its assessment of the userâ€™s interests, thereby improving the recommendation success rate for future turns.

  • â€¢

    â€¦RAARâ€¦ and â€¦RARâ€¦: These are also two frequent action strategies during the conversation. In cases where an initial recommendation attempt fails, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent will adeptly adjust the action strategy by asking one or two additional questions to better understand the userâ€™s preference, ensuring that subsequent recommendations are more aligned with the userâ€™s needs. Interestingly, we find that on the LastFM dataset, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent tends to ask two additional questions, while on the other datasets, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent typically asks only one additional question. This is probably because the LastFM dataset has a very large number of attribute values, so two additional questions are required to fully clarify the userâ€™s preference.

  • â€¢

    â€¦ARR<end> and â€¦AAR<end>: These two strategies occur frequently at the end of the conversation. Once ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent has gathered sufficient information about the userâ€™s preferences, it is able to reach successful recommendation with only one or two attempts. This strategy enables ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent to swiftly hit the target item, thereby shortening the conversation and reducing repeated recommendations.

F.8 Case Study

We provide a case study on a randomly sampled user in FigureÂ A4 to demonstrate how \methodachieves strategic conversational planning. The user, who has visited some Thai restaurants before, is now looking for a nightlife venue in this conversation. \methodquickly grasps user preference by asking only three questions, and makes a successful recommendation on the first attempt. By comparison, HutCRS can also make successful recommendations but requires more questions and recommendation attempts, while MCMIPL repeatedly makes failed recommendations. Owing to the global information graph encoder, ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent can infer user preferences from historical visits (e.g, the userâ€™s preference on Thai food) without the need for explicitly queries, thus reducing conversational turns and improving the comprehension of user preferences. Moreover, the progression from broad questions (e.g., place type) to specific questions (e.g., nightlife type) exemplifies how \methodstrategically plans conversations and asks information-seeking questions, with the policy network focusing on conversation strategy planning and the Q-network specializing in precise estimation of the attribute values. This design helps ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent to quickly narrow down candidate items and improve the recommendation success rate.

F.9 Additional Analysis on Efficiency

Although training \methodrequires conducting multiple simulated rollouts for each user, we find that such design will not significantly compromise efficiency compared with the baseline CRS methods. Under the same training pipeline with a single Tesla V100 GPU, \methodwith 20 rollouts per user takes 698 seconds per 100 gradient descent steps on the LastFM dataset and 1049 seconds per 100 gradient descent steps on the Amazon-Book dataset on average, which is about twice as slow as the two competitive baselines (HutCRS: 305 seconds/100 steps on LastFM, 465 seconds/100 steps on Amazon-Book; MCMIPL: 429 seconds/100 steps on LastFM, 548 seconds/100 steps on Amazon-Book). This is because the simulation process only requires forward calculation without the need for gradient backward update, so even conducting 20 rollouts per user will only reduce the training speed by half. Moreover, ğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒâ¢-eğš‚ğ™°ğ™¿ğ™¸ğ™´ğ™½ğšƒ-e\mathop{\mathtt{SAPIENT\text{-e}}}\limitstypewriter_SAPIENT -e takes 397 seconds per 100 gradient descent steps on the LastFM dataset and 593 seconds per 100 gradient descent steps on the Amazon-Book dataset on average, which is highly comparable to baselines. Furthermore, we note that during inference, the efficiency of \methodis comparable with baseline methods, because no tree search is required during inference, and the number of parameters for ğš‚â¢-agentğš‚-agent\mathop{\mathtt{S}\text{-agent}}\limitstypewriter_S -agent (1.30M on Yelp, 3.30M on LastFM, 2.65M on Amazon-Book, 6.48M on MovieLens) is also budget-friendly. For these reasons, we think that it is worthwhile to introduce conversational tree search for CRS, because such design only slightly compromises efficiency during training, and the training efficiency can also be improved by adopting parallel acceleration methods for MCTS Chaslot etÂ al. (2008).
